references: Geupel, Geoffrey R. and Grant Ballard. 2002. Wrentit (Chamaea fasciata), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/654.

Laudenslayer, Jr., William F. and Monica D. Parisi. 2007.  Species Notes for Wrentit (Chamaea fasciata): California Wildlife Habitat Relationships (CWHR) System Level II Model Prototype. California Department of Fish and Game.

Zeiner, D. C., W. F. Laudenslayer Jr., and K. E. Mayer (editors). 1990. California's Wildlife. Vol. 2. Birds. California Statewide Wildlife Habitat Relat. System, California. Resources Agency, Dept. Fish and Game, Sacramento, California.
habitat_description:
The Wrentit (Chamaea fasciata) is a common species of cismontane chaparral shrublands along the coasts of California and Oregon (Zeiner et al. 1990).  It is absent on the Channel Islands and areas east of the Cascade-Sierra Nevada crest in Great Basin and southeastern deserts, except in small numbers into southwestern Modoc County, CA and into eastern Plumas County, CA (Zeiner et al. 1990). 
The habitats that this species utilizes include blue oak woodlands; blue oak-foothill pine communities; chamise-redshank chaparral; closed-cone pine-cypress; coastal oak woodlands; coastal scrub with or without sage; douglas fir forests; Jeffrey pine; Central Valley blackberry and California grape (Vitis californica) patches; Klamath mixed conifer; mixed chaparral; California montane chaparral with manzanitas and lilac; Oregon hard montane chaparral with huckleberry (Vaccinium sp.) and salal (Gaultheria shallon); montane hardwoods; montane conifers; montane riparian habitats; ponderosa pines; redwood forests; sierra mixed conifers;  coyote bush (Baccharis sp.) and blackberry (Rubus sp.) thickets; urban; valley foothill riparian habitats; valley oak woodlands; and white fir forests; foothill and desert shrublands of chamise (Adenostoma fasciculatum), California lilac (Ceanothus sp.), manzanita (Arctostaphylos sp.), scrubby oaks, and even mesquite (Prosopis sp.); and early successional forests (Zeiner et al. 1990, Geupel and Ballard 2002, Laudenslayer et al. 2007).  In coniferous forests where the species is found, the shrub understory is used; the presence of shrubs is an essential element of suitable habitat (Laudenslayer et al. 2007).  Geupel and Ballard (2002) reported that the species doesn’t use Eucalyptus groves but Laudenslayer et al. (2007) included them as suitable habitat.

Although this species is especially sedentary, post-breeding movement up slopes by first year birds occurs (Zeiner et al. 1990).  The maximum reported elevations are 2,300 m, 2,500 m (8,200 ft) in the San Jacinto Mountains, and up to 2,100 m (7,000 ft) in the Yosemite area.  N. Tarr, 26Oct2012.
